content.definition:
adj. Clever at dealing with difficult situations; adept; skillful.
Her adroit handling of the boat saved us from going onto the rocks.

v. To insult or to offend deliberately.
There is no better way to affront your teammates than to suggest that they are indolent.
n. A deliberate insult or offensive act.
You will not ignore the affront to our family expressed in this letter.

n. An activity pursued for pleasure; a hobby.
Serious artists say that painting is both their profession and their avocation.

n. A prolonged, impassioned struggle for what is believed to be a just cause.
John Brown led a crusade to emancipate enslaved people.
v. To engage in such a struggle.
Paulo crusaded to eliminate prejudice from his workplace.

adj. Supplying a final answer; conclusive.
Some scholars think that the definitive biography of the poet Sylvia Plath has not yet been written.

n. Behavior; bearing.
She must have been in shock, because her demeanor didn’t change in the slightest as she watched her home go up in flames.

adj. Having or demonstrating extensive knowledge; learned.
The author provided an erudite account of the looting of artworks during World War II.
n. erudition – His rudition is evident in more than one subject.

v. 1. To install in office, sometimes with a formal ceremony.
The president of the university was inducted into office in the morning.
2. To admit to a society or to military service.
Each year the National Academy of Science inducts a few celebrated researchers.
n. induction – The induction ceremony into the Baseball Hall of Fame was a thrilling experience for the retired pitcher.

v. 1. To fall or slip from a certain level of conduct or accomplishment.
After a month of regular exercise, we lapsed into inactivity.
2. To come to an end or to expire.
I was disappointed to learn that the clothing sale had lapsed before I could make it to the store.
n. 1. A minor mistake; a slip.
A lapse of memory caused me to miss the television show last week.
2. A pause or interval.
With such voluble students, there was never a lapse in class discussion.

adj. Ready to fight, especially for a cause.
My parents, militant supporters of public education, worked with other parents and the teachers to improve the elementary school in our town.
n. One who is ready to fight for a cause.
Militants occupied the president’s office, demanding changes in the college curriculum.

n. A social outcast.
Her classmates treated Maria like a pariah when she told the teacher that someone had cheated on the test.

n. 1. A person who shows remarkable talent at an early age.
Mozart was a musical prodigy who began composing at age five.
2. An amazing or extraordinary thing or event.
Everyone flocked to see the newly invented Ferris wheel, which was regarded as a prodigy of the age of steel.

n. (masc.) protégé, (fem.) protégée – One whose training or career is helped along by another.
Tim Cook, a protégé of Steve Jobs, took over the running of Apple.

adj. 1. Rough and unpleasant to the ear.
The raucous cries of the family parrot startled the guests.
2. Boisterous and disorderly.
Before the dinner bell rang, our camp counselor let us have a pillow fight but made sure things didn’t become too raucous.

adj. Expressed without words; implied.
You gave your tacit approval by not raising any objections to our plan.

pages.name: 8A: Determining Precise Meaning
pages.subheading: Choose the most accurate paraphrase for each sentence.

content.question: The detective’s definitive report was almost complete.
options: The detective’s hastily put together report was almost complete.
The detective’s final report was almost complete.

content.question: Henry James was a very erudite author.
options: Henry James was a highly educated author.
Henry James was a prolific author.

content.question: The affront happened without warning.
options: The insulting behavior happened without warning.

content.question: The boy’s demeanor caught the attention of the school nurse.
options: The boy’s grades caught the attention of the school nurse.
The boy’s behavior caught the attention of the school nurse.

content.question: Did you hear about the prodigy who plays the piano so well?
options: Did you hear about the amazing kindergartener who plays the piano so well?
Did you hear about the professional musician who plays the piano so well?

content.question: The rivals came to a tacit agreement.
options: The rivals came to an agreement that was understood without anything being said.
The rivals came to an agreement that was witnessed and signed in a proper legal manner.

content.question: Elle is a protégé of the governor.
options: Elle’s career is being guided by the governor.
Elle is working together with the governor.

content.question: The teacher handled the students’ argument in an adroit manner.
options: The teacher handled the students’ argument in a clumsy manner.
The teacher handled the students’ argument in a skilled manner.

content.question: Sadly, Hasan’s older brother had no avocation.
options: Hasan’s older brother had no hobbies or outside interests.
Hasan’s older brother had no job or other source of income.

content.question: Maeve was a pariah to her former friends.
options: Maeve was lionized by her former friends.
Maeve was hated and shunned by her former friends.

content.question: The documentary launched a crusade to save endangered water birds.
options: The documentary launched a specially equipped boat to save endangered water birds.
The documentary launched a campaign that attempts to save endangered water birds.

content.question: Special agents are inducted into the secret society.
options: Special agents are installed as members into the secret society.
Special agents are conducting inquiries into the secret society.

content.question: His mother was anxious about his lapses.
options: His mother was anxious about his failure to follow through.
His mother was anxious about his friends and associates.

content.question: A militant group took over the meeting.
options: A group made up of army officers took over the meeting.
A group that was angry and determined took over the meeting.

content.question: Raucous laughter filled the room.

censure / criticize: “Don’t _______________ my right to free speech.”

divulge / reveal: The information he planned to _______________ was deliberately misleading.
divulge / reveal: Those actors _______________ their speeches too quickly.

cynical / skeptical: A child may become _______________ if his parents don’t keep their promises.

content.name: First Gentleman of Sports
passage: The raucous boxing fans, gathered at Madison Square Garden in New York on February 6, 1993, lapsed into silence as the announcement came over the public address system. Tennis champion Arthur Ashe had just died of pneumonia. With their response, the crowd paid their respects to a man whose presence had been felt far beyond the world of tennis. His death, though shocking, was not entirely unexpected. A year earlier, knowing that newspapers were about to reveal the fact that he was suffering from AIDS, Ashe called a news conference to announce that he had contracted the disease from infected blood he had received during heart bypass surgery in 1983.

Arthur Ashe was born in Richmond, Virginia, in 1943. When he was six, his mother died. His father, a parks policeman, was left to raise their two sons alone in a society where the races were legally segregated. Because of his father’s occupation, Ashe was allowed on the whites-only city tennis courts. He began playing on these courts at the age of seven and demonstrated a natural ability for the game. At the age of ten, he met Dr. Walter Johnson, an African American physician whose avocation was assisting young African American tennis players. “Dr. J.” recognized the young boy as a tennis prodigy and took him under his wing. The doctor arranged for his protégé to attend tennis camps and to take part in competitions.

In 1955, when Ashe was thirteen, he tried to enter a tournament in his hometown of Richmond. He was rejected because of his race. This and other such affronts to his dignity led ultimately to his crusade to change the image of tennis as a white, middle-class game. His accomplishments in this area include starting tennis programs in five major cities and helping found the National Junior Tennis League. These acts were designed to open up the game to inner-city youth.

Ashe’s calm demeanor on the tennis court earned him the respect of spectators everywhere. It was a tacit rebuke to his opponents, who often went out of their way to attract attention by hurling their rackets to the ground and engaging in other tantrums. However, Ashe’s placid manner never fooled anyone into thinking that he lacked fire. He intimidated his opponents with the ferocity of his play; his smashing serve and adroit placing of the ball (he developed sixteen variations of his backhand alone) were especially feared.

In 1968, Ashe won the U.S. Open and was ranked number one by the United States Lawn Tennis Association. Two years later he won the Australian Open. In 1975, he reached what many consider the summit of tennis achievement by winning the men’s singles title at Wimbledon. In 1980, he retired from active playing because of a heart condition, which indirectly caused his premature death. For the next five years, he captained the United States Davis Cup Team, and in 1985 he was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

In his retirement, Ashe wanted to be more than a celebrity. He served as national chairman of the American Heart Association and also raised funds for AIDS research. He proved himself to be a graceful and erudite writer. His major work, A Hard Road to Glory: A History of the African-American Athlete, published in 1988, is recognized as the definitive work on the subject.

In his memoir Days of Grace, published in 1993, Ashe says, “While blood was pouring in the streets of Birmingham, Memphis, and Biloxi...dressed in immaculate whites, I was elegantly stroking tennis balls in perfectly paved courts in California, New York, and Europe.” As if to make up for his earlier detachment from the Civil Rights Movement, Ashe became increasingly militant in his later years. He marched in protests against South Africa’s apartheid system. He protested the policy of the United States against Haitian refugees. On these and other occasions, he was arrested. Although in his memoir he writes, “I am with Thoreau, Gandhi, and Martin Luther King in their belief that violence achieves nothing but the destruction of the individual soul and the corruption of the state,” he also expresses regret that he did not see things differently earlier in life.
The state of Virginia, which had treated him and so many others of his race as pariahs, honored Ashe in his death. His body lay in state in Virginia’s capitol in Richmond as the world mourned.

content.question: How did Ashe benefit from Dr. Johnson’s avocation?
content.answer: Ashe became a protege of Dr. Johnson, who enjoyed helping young tennis players

content.question: Why did Dr. Johnson encourage and support Ashe’s tennis playing?
content.answer: He recognized Ashe’s talent as a prodigy and believed in his potential.

content.question: In what way was Ashe treated like a pariah in 1955?
content.answer: He was rejected from a tennis tournament in Richmond because of his race.

content.question: Why is it likely that Ashe would have been affronted if the newspapers had revealed he had AIDS?
content.answer: Because it would have been a violation of his privacy and dignity.

content.question: What definitive proof is there of Ashe’s paramount position in tennis?
content.answer: He was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

content.question: How did Ashe’s manner on the court compare to the way he played?
content.answer: His calm demeanor contrasted with his fierce and strategic playing style.

content.question: What is one example from the passage that shows that Ashe became more militant in expressing his values?
content.answer: He protested apartheid in South Africa and was arrested during demonstrations.

content.question: What effect did growing up in a segregated community have on Ashe’s life?
content.answer: It limited his early opportunities but also inspired his crusade to open tennis to all races.

content.question: What serves as an indication of Ashe’s erudition?
content.answer: He wrote A Hard Road to Glory, which is considered the definitive work on African American athletes.

content.question: Why was announcing he had AIDS an adroit move on Ashe’s part?
content.answer: It allowed him to control the narrative and protect his dignity before the press revealed it.

content.question: What lapse in good medical practice led to Ashe’s death?
content.answer: He received infected blood during heart surgery, which gave him AIDS.

content.question: What purpose was served by Ashe’s calm manner on the court?
content.answer: His tacit composure showed professionalism and earned respect while contrasting with his opponents’ tantrums.
